Human: Is opioid addiction a major problem today?

Assistant: That is a challenging question and one I do not have the appropriate context to answer.  I do know that some prescription drugs have side effects which can lead to tolerance and dependence.  But this question is difficult to answer on its own because I do not know how big this issue is.  This is like asking if there are many robberies in the world.  Without context we don’t know if this is a huge problem or if it is not an issue at all.

Human: Is there a lot of opioid abuse going on?

Assistant: Yes, that seems true.  I’ve heard the expression “Addiction is a chronic, relapsing brain disease” used in describing this phenomenon.

Human: Are the doctors who prescribe opioids partly to blame?

Assistant: Sure, many of the doctors who prescribe opioids do not give good advice and may have very little education in addiction and treatment.  For example, there are certain symptoms of withdrawal that would suggest a person has developed a dependence on the medication.  Often, doctors neglect to recognize these symptoms and may end up prescribing more opioids.  The resulting withdrawal symptoms can make the person feel very uncomfortable, but a doctor may not recognize the symptoms as indicative of dependence and continue prescribing.  And when a doctor prescribes, they often don’t take the time to do so in a cautious way.  Sometimes they will give high doses of the drugs because they know that they will soon have to prescribe again.  This tends to increase the addiction problems.  Also, many doctors in the US do not have a background in addiction medicine, and some also have a tendency to just dismiss the patients and don’t feel that a patient’s addiction is as important as other concerns.  There are also problems related to opioid painkillers like Oxycontin and other forms of medication such as Vicodin and Percocet.  It is not unusual for patients to become hooked on these painkillers, and then the doctor will prescribe another one.  This can cause a vicious cycle of addiction which is difficult to end.

Human: Are there any regulations that stop doctors from prescribing them when they shouldn't?

Assistant:
chosen: The CDC does put in place many regulations for opioids like Percocet and Vicodin, but many doctors still do not comply.  It is difficult to evaluate whether this is really working.  Additionally, there are a few states where physicians and pharmacists can prescribe narcotic drugs without the requirement of a prescription.  This law is very controversial.  One benefit to this system is that it allows doctors to use a “compounding pharmacy” which creates unique formulations for each patient’s particular needs.  For example, one patient might need a very small dose of medication, and another patient might need a larger dose.  The compounding pharmacy can tailor the medications for each patient's particular needs.  This does not generally cause problems, but because it is not as common in the United States as other countries, it can be hard to determine if it is truly a good idea.
rejected: Yes, there are laws in place which aim to stop doctors from prescribing drugs to their patients which they have a tendency to abuse.  This is done by reporting suspicious prescribing, by making doctors take classes in addiction, and by creating a way for doctors to report when they are concerned that their patients may have become dependent on a drug.  There are also laws which make it harder to prescribe or refill prescriptions of painkillers in certain states, such as Rhode Island.  These measures have led to a decrease in opioid overdoses, but it’s hard to know if they have been effective in reducing addiction problems.

There are also laws which make it harder to prescribe or refill prescriptions of painkillers in certain states, such as Rhode Island.  These measures have led to a decrease in opioid overdoses, but it’s hard to know if they have been effective in reducing addiction problems.

One benefit to this system is that it allows doctors to use a “compounding pharmacy” which creates unique formulations for each patient’s particular needs.  For example, one patient might need a very small dose of medication, and another patient might need a larger dose. This does not generally cause problems, but because it is not as common in the United States as other countries, it can be hard to determine if it is truly a good idea.
